label: PTX058 | Tamoxifen
source_kow: PP-LFER, Ulrich, N., Endo, S., Brown, T.N., Watanabe, N., Bronner, G., Abraham, M.H., Goss, K.-U., UFZ-LSER database v 3.2.1 [Internet], Leipzig, Germany, Helmholtz Centre for Environmental Research-UFZ. 2017 [accessed on 11.08.2023]. Available from http://www.ufz.de/lserd
source_melting_point: Jean-Claude Bradley Open Melting Point Dataset
moa_drugbank:
Tamoxifen competitively inhibits estrogen binding to its receptor, which is critical for it's activity in breast cancer cells.[A1025] Tamoxifen leads to a decrease in tumor growth factor Î± and insulin-like growth factor 1, and an increase in sex hormone binding globulin.[A1025] The increase in sex hormon binding globulin limits the amount of freely available estradiol.[A1025] These changes reduce levels of factors that stimulate tumor growth.[A1025]

Tamoxifen has also been shown to induce apoptosis in estrogen receptor positive cells.[A182195] This action is thought to be the result of inhibition of protein kinase C, which prevents DNA synthesis.[A182195] Alternate theories for the apoptotic effect of tamoxifen comes from the approximately 3 fold increase in intracellular and mitochondrial calcium ion levels after administration or the induction of tumor growth factor Î².[A182195]
protein_binding: The protein binding of tamoxifen in plasma is over 98% and mostly to serum albumin.[A182207]

aop.AOP_name: Antagonist binding to PPARα leading to body-weight loss
PPARα activation in utero leading to impaired fertility in males
Androgen receptor antagonism leading to adverse effects in the male foetus (mammals)
LXR activation leading to hepatic steatosis
AhR activation leading to hepatic steatosis
NR1I3 (CAR) suppression leading to hepatic steatosis
NFE2L2/FXR activation leading to hepatic steatosis
Epigenetic modification of PPARG leading to adipogenesis
Unknown MIE leading to reproductive dysfunction via increased HIF-1alpha transcription
Aryl hydrocarbon receptor activation leading to uroporphyria
EGFR Activation Leading to Decreased Lung Function
Anticoagulant rodenticide inhibition of vitamin K epoxide reductase resulting coagulopathy and hemorrhage
Estrogen receptor activation leading to breast cancer
Glucocorticoid Receptor activation leading to hepatic steatosis

targets: Nuclear receptor subfamily 1 group I member 2
